abstracts.cdata!:
This report is a project performance
            review of the First Highway Project in Sudan. The reach of
            Sudan's modern transport facilities is very limited,
            leaving vast areas with only primitive means of access. The
            4,800 km railway system, the principal means of transporting
            exports and imports to and from Port Sudan, is unable to
            meet the demands placed upon it. Of the almost 16,000 km of
            roads, only about 1,700 km mostly in the Khartoum-Port Sudan
            corridor are paved (only 330 km in 1970); much of the rest
            of the road network, particularly in the more populated and
            developed areas, is built on heavy clay soils rendering them
            impassable during the (June-October) rainy season. River
            transport is the major surface link to the south, but
            operational difficulties hinder its efficiency and
            reliability. Air transport is constrained because most of
            Sudan's 20 airports are subject to closure during
            seasonal rains due to soft runways; only Khartoum, Port
            Sudan and Juba airports are paved; and air traffic control
            and navigational communications are limited and unreliable.

docna.cdata!:
Sudan - Highway Project : Credit 0331 -
            Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Sudan - Highway Project : Credit
            0331 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Highway Maintenance Project
            comprises: (i) provision of consulting services to the DOR
            for: (a) improving its organization and operations, with
            emphasis on a highway betterment and maintenance program;
            (b) identifying high priority road construction projects;
            and (c) carrying out feasibility studies of about 500 km of
            high priority roads identified under (b) above, followed by
            detailed engineering of about 350 km of these roads; (ii)
            purchase of highway maintenance, workshop, and laboratory
            equipment; spare parts for both new and existing equipment
            in these categories and materials and supplies for highway
            betterment workshop construction; and (iii) technical
            assistance to the MOT in transport planning and
            coordination, and in staff training.
